veAUXOConversionBanner: Conversion 100 DOUGH = 1 AUXO, see the next step for details
xAUXOConversionBanner: Conversion 100 DOUGH = 1 AUXO, see the next step for details
veAUXODisclaimerBanner: Previous locks which are not boosted are re-locked for the remaining months.
xAUXODisclaimerBanner: This conversion is irreversible. You can buy and sell xAUXO tokens but you cannot convert them back to AUXO
DOUGHtoAUXO: DOUGH will be converted to AUXO at 100:1 rate (ex. ‚Äú‚Äù)
AUXOtoVeAUXOxAUXO: You choose whether to receive veAuxo or xAuxo
faq1Answer:
We're migrating locked DOUGH to locked AUXO. You will be able to choose to lock AUXO as veAUXO or xAUXO. Only veDOUGH holders will be able to migrate their DOUGH locks to veAUXO or xAUXO.

‚ö†Ô∏è If you're looking for options for DOUGH, or eDOUGH please go to https://piedaoorg.on.fleek.co/#/buyback
faq2: What are the differences between veDOUGH and veAUXO staking?
faq2Answer:
The main difference is that, with veDOUGH, users can have multiple locks in the same wallet.

  • veDOUGH locks are created when somebody stakes DOUGH for veDOUGH, and expire at a certain point in time. Staking multiple times creates multiple locks, with separate expiry dates.
  • veAUXO has a single-lock mechanism. All veAUXO locked by the user will expire at the same time. Additional locked AUXO can be added, and unless specified, this will expire at the same time as existing veAUXO.
faq3: What shall I choose: veAUXO or xAUXO?
faq3Answer:
• Choose veAUXO if you are willing to commit to active governance while receiving the highest possible return (rewards).
  • Choose xAUXO if you are willing to trade off part of your returns (rewards) for holding a liquid staking derivative and delegate decisions to veAUXO holders.
veAUXO is a non-transferable asset that will allow you to get monthly rewards for governing the DAO. It receives more rewards, can be redeemed for AUXO after the lock expiration, and has the option to exit to its staking derivative (xAUXO) by paying a premium.xAUXO is staking derivative build on top of veAUXO. It is a transferable asset that will allow you to get monthly rewards without the need to participate in governance. Holding a staking derivative and being governance-agnostic has a price: you get fewer rewards compared to veAUXO, and won‚Äôt be able to claim AUXO as the lock does not expire.
faq4Answer:
Option 1: Migrate all your DOUGH locks (aggregate) to one single lock to either veAUXO or xAUXO.Option 2: Migrate your DOUGH locks to either veAUXO or xAUXO one by one to individual addresses.Option 3: Combination of the above (single lock/s to veAUXO and aggregate the remaining to xAUXO, or vice versa)

Notes:(a) You can choose to boost your lock to MAX (36 months) only when aggregating veAUXO locks ‚Äî which will also reset your lock start date and gives you the best AUXO:veAUXO ratio.(b) Aggregation can only be done in the wallet that holds the DOUGH locks ‚Äî this is true for veAUXO and xAUXO.(c) Single locking for veAUXO will be possible only on wallets with no DOUGH or AUXO locks.(d) Single locks are migrated in an order determined by the contract: longest locks first.(e) The same wallet can hold veAUXO and xAUXO.
faq5: What happens if I aggregate all locks?
faq5Answer:
All your DOUGH locks will be merged into one lock. For veAUXO, the new lock duration will be determined by the remaining time to expiration of your longest DOUGH lock (amount of months until its expiration date) ‚Äî impacting the amount of veAUXO received. The end date will be derived from adding the new lock‚Äôs duration to the date you migrated.

In case you decide to boost your lock, you will be locking for 36 months and updating the start date to the transaction date. The amount of veAUXO will be the highest in regard to their staking curve.

Examples:(a) You choose to migrate to veAUXO aggregating your locks without boosting. Let‚Äôs consider your longest lock to have 10 months left for expiration. Your new lock in this case will equal to locking AUXO in a new single lock for 10 months and the amount of veAUXO received would be subject to the staking curve for a 10 months commitment.(b) You choose to migrate to veAUXO aggregating your locks and boosting. Let‚Äôs consider your longest lock to have 10 months left for expiration. Your new lock in this case will result in locking AUXO in a new single lock for 36 months with a reset in the start date and the amount of veAUXO received would be equal to locking AUXO for 36 months.(c) You choose to migrate to xAUXO aggregating your locks. The DOUGH on your locks will be migrated to AUXO(100:1 ratio), and you will receive an amount of xAUXO subject to the AUXO:xAUXO ratio (TBD).
faq6: What happens if I migrate my locks individually?
faq6Answer:
Migrating locks individually will allow you to move each lock to a new wallet (1 lock, 1 wallet) ‚Äî the destination wallets should not hold any locks. You can choose to migrate 1 lock to your DOUGH lock holding address, or individual locks to different addresses.

Note: Only 1 veAUXO lock per address is allowed. If your wallet holds multiple locks and you migrate only one to veAUXO on it you will not be able to aggregate the rest to veAUXO anymore on it ‚Äî the remaining locks will either need to be migrated to other wallets, migrated to xAUXO or remain as veDOUGH.
faq7: What are the implications of picking the current vs new wallet?
faq7Answer:
• Aggregating veAUXO ‚Üí Allowed only in the same wallet ‚Äî Not possible if it holds a veAUXO lock, but possible if it holds an xAUXO lock.
  • Single veAUXO locks ‚Üí Allowed in the same or a new wallet ‚Äî Can co-exist with an xAUXO lock in either. Not possible to aggregate veAUXO at a later stage in the same wallet if a single lock is created.
  • Aggregating xAUXO ‚Üí Allowed only in the same wallet ‚Äî Possible if it holds other xAUXO or even a veAUXO lock.
  • Single xAUXO lock ‚Üí Allowed in the same or a new wallet ‚Äî Can co-exist with other xAUXO locks in either and aggregate in the same wallet.
faq8: My locks expire next month, why can I only stake them for 6 months?
faq8Answer: The duration of non-boosted locks migrated to veAUXO are determined by the remaining time to expiration of your longest vDOUGH lock (amount of months until its expiration date). Yet, if the amount of months are lower than the minimum lock time (6 months), then your new lock will be automatically set to the minimum.
faq9: I made a mistake and chose the incorrect option, can I revert?
faq9Answer: You can't, so don‚Äôt rush. You can always reach out on Discord for assistance.
faq10: Why is my veDOUGH balance greater than the resulting veAUXO?
faq10Answer:
The migration is about moving your locked DOUGH to AUXO, and then staking AUXO for either veAUXO or xAUXO. During that process, there‚Äôre three ratios that apply:

  • DOUGH:AUXO ratio:The DOUGH to AUXO conversion is set at 100:1. This has been set in order to define the AUXO supply and to factor in the DOUGH supply after completing the burning of the Treasury-owned DOUGH.
  • AUXO:veAUXO ratio:The number of veAUXO obtained by staking AUXO is determined by two elements: the locked amount and the time commitment (6 to 36 months), following the curve: y=x/k*log(x) ‚Äî just as veDOUGH did.
  • AUXO:xAUXO ratio:The number of xAUXO obtained by staking AUXO is determined by this ratio which is subject to a minting fee. This minting fee has not yet been defined, and for testing purposes has been set to zero.
faq11: I have questions...a lot. Where can I go?
faq11Answer: Join us at Discord and it will be taken care of
faq12: What happens if I don't migrate on time?
faq12Answer:
Your remaining locked DOUGH will be unlocked, and you will be able to claim it. There won't be future migrations.

‚ö†Ô∏è If you don't migrate by April 2023 (to be ratified) you won't be able to migrate at all!
faq13: What will happen to any DOUGH after the migration?
faq13Answer: DOUGH will always be with us ‚Äî yet it won‚Äôt serve any purpose in the Auxo DAO. DOUGH won‚Äôt be migrated, and its utility, issuance, burning, and liquidity provision will be halted by the time the migration starts. Holders will be able to trade it as long as there‚Äôs a secondary market for it. Any secondary market will neither be promoted nor supported by the DAO.
faq14: I‚Äôm a veDOUGH holder, and I want out. What can I do?
faq14Answer: After the migration DOUGH will be unlocked and available for claiming.
faq15Answer: Every month the DAO Treasury will distribute rewards to veAUXO and xAUXO stakers that come from the Treasury Farming operations. Both xAUXO and veAUXO holders will receive rewards, but the veAUXO rewards distributed per token will be higher than the xAUXO rewards per token: reflecting the premium placed on having a liquid token, and not having a need to govern the DAO. In other words, veAUXO holders get 60% of the profit from the Treasury-farmed assets, while xAUXO holders will get proportionally less, as if 40% was distributed instead.
faq16Answer: veAUXO token holders will benefit from direct on-chain governance capabilities and their share will enable them to vote and govern the DAO. For veAUXO holders voting is an action required to be eligible for the monthly rewards distribution. On the other hand, xAUXO holders do not benefit from these governance capabilities, as they delegate the work to the veAUXO holders as part of the trade-off for being liquid. Instead of voting, xAUXO holders require to stake their token in order to be eligible for the monthly rewards distribution.
faq17Answer: veAUXO is a non-transferable token, meaning that it will stay in the wallet chosen until the lock is over and can be unlocked and redeemed for AUXO. In comparison, xAUXO is a transferable token that can be transferred freely, as it‚Äôs a liquid staking derivative of veAUXO.
faq18Answer: AUXO holders choosing to stake to veAUXO will be able to select a lock period between 6 and 36 months, and once locked can opt-in to boost their position ‚Äî once the lock is over veAUXO holders can redeem their tokens and get back their AUXO.veAUXO holders choosing to migrate to xAUXO will be locking AUXO perpetuity, meaning that they won‚Äôt be able to redeem xAUXO for AUXO at any given point in the future.
faq19Answer: AUXO introduces a way for veAUXO holders to create recurring liquidity events, also known as bonding, in order to increase treasury principal by minting tokens. Bonding to veAUXO always happens at the exact NAV price, while bonding to xAUXO is subject to premium (TBD) ‚Äî in consequence bonding to xAUXO increases the NAV price.
faq20Answer: There are no fees associated with minting veAUXO tokens. On the contrary, a mint fee (20%) may be applied when xAUXO is minted.
faq21Answer: veAUXO can only be exited at lock expiration. xAUXO can‚Äôt be exited but traded. At any given point in time, veAUXO can be locked in perpetuity by minting xAUXO (minting fee applies), and xAUXO then traded to exit the position.
